H0.text: Measuring its red shift is the way to determine the speed and general direction of motion of a galaxy relative to the Earth.

H1.text: The gravity it exerts is what can determine the speed and general direction of motion of a galaxy relative to the Earth.

H2.text: Contrasting a galaxy against nearby stars is the method by which the speed and general direction of motion of a galaxy relative to the Earth can be determined.

H3.text: Observing its motion across the sky determines the speed and general direction of a galaxy relative to the Earth.

A4.text: The Andromeda Galaxy is moving toward our own Milky Way galaxy within the Local Group; thus, when observed from Earth, its light is undergoing a blueshift.

A5.text: By measuring the broadening and shifts of the 21-centimeter hydrogen line in different directions, astronomers have been able to measure the recessional velocities of interstellar gas, which in turn reveals the rotation curve of our Milky Way.
